body:
Abstract: The Extended Spring Indices are mathematical models that predict the “start of spring” (timing of first leaf or first bloom) at a particular location. These models were constructed using historical observations of the timing of first leaf and first bloom in a cloned lilac cultivar (Syringa X chinensis ‘Red Rothomagensis’) and two cloned honeysuckle cultivars (Lonicera tatarica L. ‘Arnold Red’ and Lonicera korolkowii Stapf, also known as ‘Zabelii’). Primary inputs to the model are temperature and weather events, beginning January 1 of each year. The model outputs are first leaf and first bloom date for a given location. The Extended Spring Indices support understanding of spatial patterns in the timing of spring, including short-term forecasts to support resource management. They have also been used as an indicator of climate change by both the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Climate Assessment.  Keywords: Spring, Phenology, Climate Change, Leaf Out, Bloom, Natural Resource Management.

Data Dependencies: Daily minimum and maximum air temperatures are needed to run the model - these could be at any scale of interest - from an individual weather station, to a 100 year gridded climate dataset.

Assumptions:
1.  Phenological observations from a few key indicator species can be used to characterize spring onset in a way that is relevant to a wide range of ecological and climatic transitions at the start of spring.
2.  Where moisture  availability  is  not a  factor,  plant  phenological responses   reﬂect   the   accumulated   effects   of   temperature ﬂuctuations in conjunction with increasing day length.
3.  Near surface temperatures in temperate regions do not increase monotonically  during  springtime,  but  instead  ﬂuctuate  as  a consequence of large-scale (e.g., ∽1000 km) physical processes. These  phenomena  are  typically  synoptic-scale  weather  patterns  that  drive  multi-day  warm  episodes  by advecting  warm air masses in from the south.
4.  Synoptic-scale  weather  events  can  be  detected  from  meteorological observations of daily Tmin and Tmax.

Model Structure: [Growing Degree Days since Jan 1]+[Warm Spells]=[Leaf Out Day of Year]  and   [Growing Degree Days since Leaf Out Day of Year]+[Warm Spells]=[Bloom Day of Year]

Equations: See Ault et al 2015 - https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cageo.2015.06.015 - Section 2.2 for the equations

Temporal Information: Model outputs are day of year, timestep is daily.

Spatial Information: See Crimmins et al 2017 for several gridded implementations at different spatial scales that the USA-NPN has created. https://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2017/1003/ofr20171003.pdf

Limitations: The model does not incorporate moisture, so it is of limited utility in precipitation driven systems. 

Input/Output and Variables: Daily minimum and maximum air temperatures are the model inputs. Day of year (1-365) are the model ouput.

Conditions: The Leaf Out model is initiated on January 1st, assuming plant dormancy. The Bloom model takes Leaf Out date as the initial condition.

Evaluation: Detailed in Crimmins et al 2017; we compare observed to predicted lilac and honeysuckle leaf and bloom dates with this dashboard https://www.usanpn.org/data/si-x_plausibility. Gerst et al 2019  provides an evaluation of model performance.

Usage: Schwartz, Ault, and Betancourt, 2013 has 58 citations; the USA-NPN raster layers of the Spring Indices get ~500,000 downloads/year.
